title: Children of God
shortSummary: 1 John 3 reveals the profound love God has bestowed on believers, calling them His children and urging them to live righteously in light of this identity. The chapter contrasts the children of God with the children of the devil, emphasizing love, obedience, and the hope of transformation at Christ’s return.
timeline: c. AD 85-95 - Late first century, during the early Christian church's formation

keyCharacters.name: The Father
keyCharacters.description: God the Father, who bestows love and calls believers His children.

keyCharacters.name: The Son of God (Jesus Christ)
keyCharacters.description: Jesus Christ, manifested to take away sin and destroy the works of the devil.

keyCharacters.name: Cain
keyCharacters.description: Biblical figure used as an example of one who was of the wicked one and killed his brother out of evil.

definitions.definition: Believers who have been adopted into God's family through faith in Jesus Christ, reflecting a new spiritual identity.
The transgression or violation of God's law, separating humanity from God.
A metaphor for the divine nature or new life implanted in believers by God, enabling them to overcome sin.
To remain, dwell, or continue in a close, living relationship with Christ.

outline.heading: The Love and Identity of God's Children
outline.description: This section marvels at the great love God has shown by calling believers His children and speaks of the future hope of being like Christ when He appears.

outline.heading: Sin and Righteousness Defined
outline.description: John explains sin as lawlessness and contrasts those who practice righteousness with those who belong to the devil, emphasizing that true children of God do not live in habitual sin.

outline.heading: Love as the Mark of God's Children
outline.description: The command to love one another is reiterated, with Cain’s example illustrating the danger of hatred, which is equated with murder and incompatible with eternal life.

outline.heading: Christ’s Example and Our Response
outline.description: Believers are called to imitate Christ’s sacrificial love by laying down their lives for others and demonstrating love through actions, not just words.

outline.heading: Confidence in Prayer and Obedience
outline.description: The chapter concludes by encouraging believers to have assurance before God through obedience and love, promising that God hears and answers prayers when His commandments are kept.

application: Live with the assurance of being God’s child, allowing this identity to motivate holy living and hope for Christ’s return.
Reject sin and pursue righteousness, recognizing that habitual sin is inconsistent with being born of God.
Demonstrate genuine love through practical deeds, especially caring for those in need within the Christian community.
Maintain confidence in prayer by obeying God’s commandments and cultivating a sincere love for others.

keyVerses.text: Behold, what manner of love the Father hath bestowed upon us, that we should be called the sons of God: therefore the world knoweth us not, because it knew him not.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the incredible love of God in adopting believers as His children, setting the foundation for the chapter’s themes.

keyVerses.text: Whosoever is born of God doth not commit sin; for his seed remaineth in him: and he cannot sin, because he is born of God.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes the transformative power of being born of God, which enables believers to overcome sin.

keyVerses.text: Hereby perceive we the love of God, because he laid down his life for us: and we ought to lay down our lives for the brethren.
keyVerses.significance: This verse calls believers to imitate Christ’s sacrificial love as the defining mark of Christian living.

keyVerses.text: And this is his commandment, That we should believe on the name of his Son Jesus Christ, and love one another, as he gave us commandment.
keyVerses.significance: This verse summarizes the Christian duty to faith in Christ and love for one another as God’s command.
